109/22/2012

States CP

Tournament: GSU | Round: 2 | Opponent: Northwestern HM | Judge: Erin Collins

States CP – 1NC

The fifty United States state governments and relevant United States territories should incentivize oil extraction in the Alaskan Outer Continental Shelf.

The fifty United States state governments and relevant United States territories should provide tax credits to for buying vehicles based on the gas efficiency of the vehicle.

Implementing tax incentives to promote gas efficient cars foments a society which values energy conservation

Zachery W. Silverman, Georgetown University Law Center, "Hybrid Vehicles: A Practical and Effective Short-Term Solution to Petroleum Dependence", Georgetown International Environmental Law Review, lexis, 2K7

Despite the fact that it seems as though Americans are entrenched in a gas
AND
-mendable idea, but some problems remain that need to be addressed.

209/22/2012

Reg Neg CP

Tournament: GSU | Round: 2 | Opponent: Northwestern HM | Judge: Erin Collins

1NC

1NC

Text – The United States Federal Government should begin a process of negotiated rulemaking over restrictions on oil extraction in the Alaskan Outer Continental Shelf. including an announced intention to substantially reduce restrictions on oil extraction in the Alaskan Outer Continental Shelf within a year and convene affected parties for binding mediation over the substance of this policy. We’ll clarify.

Competes –

It doesn’t fiat topical action. The process is uncertain and open-ended —- mutually exclusive with the plan.

Endelman 3 (Gary, Immigration Lawyer – BP America, Inc., JD – University of Houston and Ph.D. in History – University of Delaware, "Go as Far as You Can: How Negotiated Rulemaking in Immigration Benefits America: Part 2 of 2", 7-18, http://www.ilw.com/articles/2004,0604-endelman.pdf)

Those who believe, as I do, that immigration is good for America have
AND
ideological combatants shrink back from assuming the very real risks that progress demands.   

Solvency is only possible through citizen involvement- coordination in energy policy is the vital internal link- reg neg is the appropriate structure to ensure solvecy

Sean Nolan, Associate Professor of Law and Dispute Resolution Program Director. Vermont Law School 2011 Negotiating the Wind: A Framework to Engage Citizens in Siting Wind Turbines

The U.S. has enough wind capacity to generate a significant amount of
AND
them reach agreement on the types of impacts and appropriate mitigation measures.202

Solves the whole case —- reg neg facilitates a consensus decision that’s legitimate and quickly enforced

Harter 97 (Philip J., Visiting Associate Professor and Director of the Program on Consensus, Democracy, and Governance – Vermont Law School, "Fear of Commitment: An Affliction of Adolescents", Duke Law Journal, April, 46 Duke L.J. 1389, Lexis)

The most well developed of these techniques, other than the public hearings and meetings
AND
was one of the aspects of the process they considered most valuable. 48-http://www.lexis.com/research/retrieve?_m=c2cefcf5146011fa56687a48a7cd33c3%26docnum=20%26_fmtstr=FULL%26_startdoc=1%26wchp=dGLbVtb-zSkAl%26_md5=444f442e596607894252b8bddb7955af%26focBudTerms=The%20most%20well%20developed%20of%20these%26focBudSel=all

So much of the discussion of collaborative
AND
other forms of policy. What follows is an elaboration on that process.

Sean Nolan, Associate Professor of Law and Dispute Resolution Program Director. Vermont Law School 2011 Negotiating the Wind: A Framework to Engage Citizens in Siting Wind Turbines

Despite demonstrated need and available technology, the promise of wind energy has yet to
AND
citizens and provide the substrate on which a satisfactory solution can be reached.

AND

2NC Solvency

AND
invest without a protective net of regulation that guarantees them an acceptable return. 

Don’t evaluate evidence that isn’t in the context of reg neg. Even if parties generally HATE the plan, negotiated rulemaking creates an environment of inclusion that changes their psychological orientation to produce agreement.

Freeman 00 (Jody, Acting Professor of Law – University of California Los Angeles, "The Private Role in Public Governance", New York University Law Review, June, 75 N.Y.U.L. Rev. 543, Lexis)

A2: Certainty Key – 2NC*

Certainty is a DA to the Aff —- only reg neg promotes transparency and input that are essential to public respect for the law —- plan won’t be trusted because it’s a top-down bolt from the blue —- that’s Endelman. This perception undercuts certainty and creates fear of roll-back. Only the CP solves.
Siegler 97 (Ellen, Senior Attorney – American Petroleum Institute, "Regulatory Negotiations and Other Rulemaking Processes: Strengths and Weaknesses from an Industry Viewpoint", Duke Law Journal, April, 46 Duke L.J. 1429, Lexis)

There can be benefits to participating in a successful reg neg. First, the
AND
~]  struction projects, which are costly and require years of advance planning.

Negotiation is key to legitimacy and locks-in policy change

Kobick 10 (Julia, JD Candidate – Harvard Law School, "Negotiated Rulemaking: The Next Step in Regulatory Innovation at the Food and Drug Administration?", Food and Drug Law Journal, 65 Food Drug L.J. 425, Lexis)

A2: Perm – Do Both

Links to politics – includes the plan, which crushes support ——more evidence

AND
— not the kind of bureaucratic problems that can be solved by negotiation.

Genuine key —- perm dictates a results, destroying the process

Harter 9 (Philip J., Professor of Law – University of Missouri and Member – Center for the Study of Dispute Resolution, "Collaboration: The Future of Governance", Journal of Dispute Resolution, 2009 J. Disp. Resol. 411, Lexis)

F. Role of the Agency
The agency plays an absolutely critical role in
AND
resulting synergy that is so important and beneficial in developing a powerful result.

Severs certainty —- plan must be done immediately —- key to all ground based on time-sensitive arguments —- if it doesn’t, it links because it cuts-off negotiation mid-process —- collapsing compliance

Martin 91 (Herbert J., Partner – Crowell %26 Moring, JD – Catholic University Law School, and BA and MA – Fordham University, "Alternative Dispute Resolution: Coming to Proceedings Near You", Public Utilities Fortnightly, 3-1, Lexis)

other nonbinding forms of dispute resolution may find greater favor in agency proceedings.

A2: Perm – Do the CP

"Resolved" and "should" require certainty —- plan must be "firm" and "obligated" to act – that’s American Heritage Dictionary —- CP isn’t —- makes change uncertain

"Resolved" means "to make a firm decision" and "should" is "used to imply obligation or duty"
~[American Heritage Dictionary – dictionary.com~]

09/23/2012

QER CP

Tournament: GSU | Round: 5 | Opponent: Northwestern LV | Judge: Durkee

1NC

1NC


The United States Congress should

immediately establish a government-wide staged-process Quadrennial Energy Review to recommend goals, priorities and actions for implementation of a national energy policy, led by the President in coordination with the Secretary of Energy as Executive Secretariat, giving them final authority over its content

immediately establish a deadline for completion of each stage by February 1stof each year, with a deadline for completion of the entire review by February 1st, 2014, and every subsequent four years

and immediately provide all necessary support for expedited build up of relevant analytic capabilities

The President and Executive Secretariat should immediately establish a policy determination to provide full support for making a recommendation to reduce restrictions in the United States that disproportionately affect expansion of small modular nuclear reactors   a top priority of the first stage of the review.

Experts agree it’s the single most important energy policy, spurs implementation and avoids budget fights

(Steven, DOE QTR, pdf)

AND

2NC A2:  Certainty Key

NMNP, 12  
ABOUT THE NEW MILLENIUM NUCLEAR PARTNERSHIP The New Millennium Nuclear Energy Summit was held on December 7, 2010, in Washington, D.C. Senior leaders from government, industry and non-government organizations  actively participated in defining the most important and substantive issues that confront the  nuclear energy industry—an essential part of the United States’ energy production portfolio.  Upon the success of the summit, four working groups comprised of summit participants were  established to provide the recommendations found in this consolidated report. ABOUT THIRD WAY Third Way is a think tank that answers America’s challenges with modern ideas aimed  at the center. We advocate for private-sector economic growth, a tough and smart centrist  security strategy, a clean energy revolution, and progress on divisive social issues, all through  a moderate-led U.S. politics, June pdf

and  restrain the "technology of the moment" shift in governmental priorities. 

Only holistic national policy approach key to predictability and confidence in long term investment decisions

NMNP, 12  
ABOUT THE NEW MILLENIUM NUCLEAR PARTNERSHIP The New Millennium Nuclear Energy Summit was held on December 7, 2010, in Washington, D.C. Senior leaders from government, industry and non-government organizations  actively participated in defining the most important and substantive issues that confront the  nuclear energy industry—an essential part of the United States’ energy production portfolio.  Upon the success of the summit, four working groups comprised of summit participants were  established to provide the recommendations found in this consolidated report. ABOUT THIRD WAY Third Way is a think tank that answers America’s challenges with modern ideas aimed  at the center. Economic considerations outweigh government regulations

Pietro S. Nivola¶ Senior Fellow Governance Studies Program The Brookings Institution Washington, DC 2004 "The Political Economy of Nuclear Energy in the United States" http://www.ifri.org/files/CFE/Nivola_NuclearEnergy_US.pdf-http://www.ifri.org/files/CFE/Nivola_NuclearEnergy_US.pdf

Government policies, including environmental regulations, have not been the overriding source of the nuclear industry’s tribulations in the United States over the past thirty years. Rather, the industry’s difficulties derived, first and foremost, from upheavals in energy markets following the shocks of the 1970s. Much depends, therefore, on whether the economic fundamentals of tomorrow will remain like today’s, or whether the economics of nuclear plants may turn more conducive to a resumption of investment.

Natural gas prices are a bigger internal link to development than regulatory risks

  • Lucas Davis is Assistant Professor at the Haas School of Business, University of California, Berkeley, 2011 "Prospects for U.S. Nuclear Power After Fukushima" http://ei.haas.berkeley.edu/pdf/working_papers/WP218.pdf-http://ei.haas.berkeley.edu/pdf/working_papers/WP218.pdf

In addition to these regulatory risks, investors in nuclear power also face numerous forms
AND
construction, with cost overruns borne primarily by ratepayers rather than shareholders.5

B. Multiple short term barriers block success of long term space exploration

The opportunity to explore outer space may soon pass. Some estimates are that we only have about thirty years left before a combination of factors, including space debris, electromagnetic pollution and energy limitations prevent further attempts at space exploration (Gott, 1 993). Space exploration is expensive and projects for manned expeditions to far-off planets are likely to be curtailed in a  cost-conscious society.

09/24/2012

States CP vs. HTGCR Aff

Tournament: GSU | Round: Octos | Opponent: Wake Forest LM | Judge: Sherry Hall, Nick Miller, Buntin

1NC

The fifty United States state governments and relevant United States territories should substantially increase their High Temperature Gas-Cooled Reactor energy production funding in the United States. The fifty United States state governments and relevant United States territories should provide research and development subsidies, construction credits, loan guarantees, investment tax credits and consumption incentives for High Temperature Gas-Cooled Reactors. The fifty United States state governments and relevant United States territories should form constitutional commissions to uniformly amend their respective state constitutions to allow the state to run a limited deficit.  The National Governors Association should create a State Reserve Bank system. The fifty United States state governments and relevant United States territories should permit the collection of interest costs and return on equity during construction of nuclear power plants by establishing a Construction Work in Progress mechanism that uses state funds to offset the costs. All 50 states should offer all necessary investment incentives in the form of escalating investor tax credits and cash grants to each company participating in the Next Generation Nuclear Plant Demonstration Project that increases their financial investment in the project by over 50%. The fifty United States state governments and relevant United States territories should increase financing for United States businesses engaging in High Temperature Gas-Cooled Reactor projects with the People’s Republic of China.

State incentives programs solve – they can drive the market towards widespread alternative energy acceptance

Elizabeth Brown, Patrick Quinlan, Harvey M. Sachs, and Daniel Williams, Am. Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, March 2002, "Tax Credits for Energy Efficiency," http://aceee.org/pubs/e021full.pdf?CFID=1059758%26CFTOKEN=72603414

AND
residents. the United States and its citizens, and the global climate.

*2NC - incentives to give fund to DOE solve whole aff

The demonstration program already exists – its legally required

Gibbs and Soto ’9 (Document ID: PLN-2825 Revision ID: 1 Effective Date: 09/30/09 Preliminary Project Execution Plan Project No. 23843 Greg Gibbs, Project Director, Rafael Soto, Deputy Project Director
The Next Generation Nuclear Plant (NGNP) represents an integration of high-temperature reactor
technology with advanced hydrogen, electricity, and process heat production capabilities, thereby meeting
the mission need identified by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE). The strategic goal of the NGNP
Project is to broaden the environmental and economic benefits of nuclear energy technology to the U.S.
economy by demonstrating its applicability to market sectors not served by light water reactors and
drawing their energy needs from fossil fuels.
The NGNP Project will be a Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC)-licensed plant that
AND
operational by 2021, as required by the Environmental Policy Act of 2005.

acceptable option; China must  develop programs to provide and train its workers. 

b. public backlash

Lyons et al. ’9 ((~~[Blythe J. Lyons, John R. Lyman, Mihaela Carstei, and General Richard L. Lawson (USAF), "United States-China Cooperation On Nuclear Power: An Opportunity for Fostering Sustainable Energy Security", Atlantic Council, 3-4/3-6 2009, http://www.acus.org/files/publication_pdfs/65/AtlanticCouncil-USChinaNuclearPower.pdf-http://www.acus.org/files/publication_pdfs/65/AtlanticCouncil-USChinaNuclearPower.pdf, Based on the Dialogue Sponsored by the Atlantic Council and the U.S./China Energy and Environment Technology Center

Public acceptance: A recent survey of public  acceptance of nuclear power showed that the public  knows little about the development of nuclear power in  China. Out of six forms of energy, nuclear ranks fourth in  acceptance behind solar, hydropower and natural gas,  but much better than acceptance of coal power. Safety  is the number one concern, followed by concerns about  its impact on the environment.

c. manufacturing capacity

Lyons et al. ’9 ((~~[Blythe J. Lyons, John R. Lyman, Mihaela Carstei, and General Richard L. Lawson (USAF), "United States-China Cooperation On Nuclear Power: An Opportunity for Fostering Sustainable Energy Security", Atlantic Council, 3-4/3-6 2009, http://www.acus.org/files/publication_pdfs/65/AtlanticCouncil-USChinaNuclearPower.pdf-http://www.acus.org/files/publication_pdfs/65/AtlanticCouncil-USChinaNuclearPower.pdf, Based on the Dialogue Sponsored by the Atlantic Council and the U.S./China Energy and Environment Technology Center

Supply chain: Significant ramp up of nuclear power  plant construction exposes potential problem areas,  particularly in the engineering and large equipment  manufacturing sectors. It is expected that the supply  chain can be expanded over time as demand grows.

10/03/2012

CP vs Military SMRs

Tournament: KYRR | Round: 3 | Opponent: NW LV | Judge: 

1NC

The United States Federal Government, should:

Through alternate means obtain electricity from small modular reactors for Department of Energy and other non- military federal lands for 30 years and should amend any conflicting requirements to narrowly exempt that act.

make available loans, loan guarantees, transferable production and investment tax credits for small modular reactors

provide full funding for more robust detailed design and engineering efforts and should offer cost sharing for other first of a kind expenses for each distinct design, including licensing, construction, manufacturing and production costs.

Establish a parity option for licensing small modular reactors

provide full funding and support to the NRC for expedited review of licensing issues related to small modular reactors.

obtain, through alternative financing, advanced microgrids for military bases in the United States, maximized to account for site specific energy factors.

Necessary funding should not be provided from existing funds or programs of the Department of Energy, the Department of Defense, or the Nuclear Review Commission.  Necessary funding should be provided through creation of a non-budgetary funding stream placing a 1 mill per kilowatt surcharge on commercial electricity and a 2 cents per gallon surcharge on non-federal transportation fuel.  Additional funding should be provided through designating a necessary portion of federal oil and gas royalty revenue.

Even single Power Purchase Agreement solves – DOD not key

King 11
Marcus King, Ph.D., Center for Naval Analyses Project Director and Research Analyst for the Environment and Energy TeamLaVar Huntzinger, Thoi Nguyen, March 2011, Feasibility of Nuclear Power on U.S.Military Installations, www.cna.org/sites/default/files/research/Nuclear Power on Military Installations D0023932 A5.pdf

10/04/2012

States CP

Tournament: KYRR | Round: 5 | Opponent:  | Judge: 

The 50 States should provide full and upfront funding for all robust detailed design and engineering efforts for small modular reactors as well as all licensing costs.  The scope of such detailed design and engineering effort will include preparation of construction drawings; the specification of system components; procurement engineering, including the preparation of bid packages for suppliers; a general site layout, and all nonrecurring design and engineering work at the manufacturing site.

The fifty United States state governments and relevant United States territories should form constitutional commissions to uniformly amend their respective state constitutions to allow the state to run a limited deficit.  The National Governors Association should create a State Reserve Bank system.

More robust detailed design and engineering efforts solve expedited license approval, cost confidence and widespread commercialization

Burnes et al, 12
JOHN BURNES, MICHAEL MCBRIDE, JANNA CHESNO, Van Ness Feldman, Van Ness Feldman maintains one of the most active and prominent LNG practices in the U.S.  Our practice includes the review and negotiation of LNG sale, purchase, and tolling agreements, and due diligence reviews of proposed projects and contracts for financing LNG facilities.  Our team has first-hand experience in obtaining LNG-related permits from DOE and the needed authorizations to construct and operate LNG terminals and related pipeline facilities from FERC.  Further, Van Ness Feldman professionals have worked on every piece of federal energy legislation over the last two decades.  In addition to our representation of existing U.S. pipelines and LNG terminal owners, our team includes members who litigated the Trunkline LNG Project before FERC and DOE where the issue of DOE’s revocation authority arose for the first time, and members with first-hand experience in developing the statutory language of Energy Policy Act of 2005, which facilitated the development of LNG import terminals in the U.S.  For more information, please contact John Burnes, Janna Chesno, Lisa Epifani, Michael McBride, or any member of our LNG practice at 202.298.1800., January 23, 2012, http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html-http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html)

10/04/2012

TPP Condition CP

Tournament: KY RR | Round: 7 | Opponent: Mary Wash | Judge: JP

1NC Condition CP

Text: The Department of Energy should approve currently pending applications for LNG exports.  The United States should offer to exempt future LNG exports from section 3 of the Natural Gas Act of 1938 to nations for which the US has extended the status of Permanent Normal Trade Relations and that agree to trade negotiations with the United States, in particular offering Japan an exemption pending approval of TPP participation.

CP Solves LNG Exports -~— avoids politics and allows for successful TPP negotiations

Burnes et al, 12
JOHN BURNES, MICHAEL MCBRIDE, JANNA CHESNO, Van Ness Feldman, Van Ness Feldman maintains one of the most active and prominent LNG practices in the U.S.  Our practice includes the review and negotiation of LNG sale, purchase, and tolling agreements, and due diligence reviews of proposed projects and contracts for financing LNG facilities.  Our team has first-hand experience in obtaining LNG-related permits from DOE and the needed authorizations to construct and operate LNG terminals and related pipeline facilities from FERC.  Further, Van Ness Feldman professionals have worked on every piece of federal energy legislation over the last two decades.  In addition to our representation of existing U.S. pipelines and LNG terminal owners, our team includes members who litigated the Trunkline LNG Project before FERC and DOE where the issue of DOE’s revocation authority arose for the first time, and members with first-hand experience in developing the statutory language of Energy Policy Act of 2005, which facilitated the development of LNG import terminals in the U.S.  For more information, please contact John Burnes, Janna Chesno, Lisa Epifani, Michael McBride, or any member of our LNG practice at 202.298.1800., January 23, 2012, http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html-http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html)

10/04/2012

LNG Restrictions CP

Tournament: KY RR | Round: 7 | Opponent: Mary Wash | Judge: JP

1NC LNG Restrictions CP

The United States Federal Government should maintain its authorization restrictions on natural gas liquefication facilities.

The United States Federal Government should add to existing legal penalties for violations of authorization restrictions on natural gas liquefication facilities an alternate penalty option allowing violators to choose penalization solely through entry into a Supplemental Environmental Program requiring payment of 1% of revenue from all violating activities to an Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion Trust Fund managed by dedicated non-profit organizations, conducted in co-ordination with, and with oversight by, the Department of Energy, to support the development and commercialization of Ocean Therman Energy Conversion, with an initial focus on providing financing for a 10 megawatt pilot project demonstration plant. Implementation of the Supplemental Environmental Program should provide a shield from additional legal penalties stemming from the violating action, including citizen suits and penalties under state law.  Any conflicting federal laws and regulations should be modified to provide a narrow exemption for the above act.

Weak penalties do not alter the restriction but ensure it is functionally ignored

CPR, ’8  
Center for Progressive Reform, http://progressiveregulation.org/perspectives/environEnforce.html-http://progressiveregulation.org/perspectives/environEnforce.html

Effective enforcement … by Congress for citizen enforcers.

That’s specifically true of Supplemental Environmental Programs with weak penalties

(  ) Bataille’s premise of inevitable extinction is simply wrong:

Expedited Review CP v LNG Terminals Aff - 1NC

Tournament: Kentucky | Round: 7 | Opponent: Mary Washington MM | Judge: Leah Mocszulski

Expedited Review CP – 1NC

The Department of Energy should determine that liquid natural gas exports to countries which the United States has Permanent Normal Trade Relations with are in the public interest.  The United States Federal Government should provide the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission with all necessary resources and funding to provide expedited review assessing whether liquid natural gas export terminals comply with existing Federal Energy Regulatory Commission restrictions.

DOE review of studies determines the export outcome and solves predictability

Burnes et al, 12
JOHN BURNES, MICHAEL MCBRIDE, JANNA CHESNO, Van Ness Feldman, Van Ness Feldman maintains one of the most active and prominent LNG practices in the U.S.  Our practice includes the review and negotiation of LNG sale, purchase, and tolling agreements, and due diligence reviews of proposed projects and contracts for financing LNG facilities.  Our team has first-hand experience in obtaining LNG-related permits from DOE and the needed authorizations to construct and operate LNG terminals and related pipeline facilities from FERC.  Further, Van Ness Feldman professionals have worked on every piece of federal energy legislation over the last two decades.  In addition to our representation of existing U.S. pipelines and LNG terminal owners, our team includes members who litigated the Trunkline LNG Project before FERC and DOE where the issue of DOE’s revocation authority arose for the first time, and members with first-hand experience in developing the statutory language of Energy Policy Act of 2005, which facilitated the development of LNG import terminals in the U.S.  For more information, please contact John Burnes, Janna Chesno, Lisa Epifani, Michael McBride, or any member of our LNG practice at 202.298.1800., January 23, 2012, http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html-http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html)

The study was requested by DOE to evaluate the "cumulative impacts" that the
AND
of increased LNG exports and DOE’s authority, is also likely in 2012.

The only DOE regulation is an assessment of public interest

Burnes et al, 12
JOHN BURNES, MICHAEL MCBRIDE, JANNA CHESNO, Van Ness Feldman, Van Ness Feldman maintains one of the most active and prominent LNG practices in the U.S.  Our practice includes the review and negotiation of LNG sale, purchase, and tolling agreements, and due diligence reviews of proposed projects and contracts for financing LNG facilities.  Our team has first-hand experience in obtaining LNG-related permits from DOE and the needed authorizations to construct and operate LNG terminals and related pipeline facilities from FERC.  Further, Van Ness Feldman professionals have worked on every piece of federal energy legislation over the last two decades.  In addition to our representation of existing U.S. pipelines and LNG terminal owners, our team includes members who litigated the Trunkline LNG Project before FERC and DOE where the issue of DOE’s revocation authority arose for the first time, and members with first-hand experience in developing the statutory language of Energy Policy Act of 2005, which facilitated the development of LNG import terminals in the U.S.  For more information, please contact John Burnes, Janna Chesno, Lisa Epifani, Michael McBride, or any member of our LNG practice at 202.298.1800., January 23, 2012, http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html-http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html)

When DOE considers a request to export LNG, it must determine whether the proposed
AND
DOE’s claimed authority to do so has not been judicially affirmed.~i~ 

We’ll submit a list of every FERC restriction on LNGs – Every single one is assessing environmental compliance – irrelevant to overall decision on exports

FERC, 10  (6/28, http://ferc.gov/industries/gas/indus-act/lng/state-rights.asp-http://ferc.gov/industries/gas/indus-act/lng/state-rights.asp**)**

Industries  Natural Gas Industry Activities   LNG
AND
and can contribute to the complete environmental review of the proposal. 

Here’s more proof – the process review just assesses public interest based on compliance with environmental standards

FERC, 10  (6/28, http://ferc.gov/industries/gas/indus-act/lng/rev-proc.asp)**
Project Review Process

FERC is involved in LNG terminals from the time they are conceived by the industry
AND
several steps that need to be taken by the developer prior to construction.

T vs LNG Terminals Aff - 1NC/1NR - Clay Round 7

Tournament: Kentucky | Round: 7 | Opponent: Mary Washington MM | Judge: Leah Mocszulski

T vs LNG Terminals Aff – 1NC – Clay Round 7

1NC T

Financial incentives require the disbursement of public funds linked to energy production – excludes action with incentive effects

Webb 93 – lecturer in the Faculty of Law at the University of Ottawa (Kernaghan, "Thumbs, Fingers, and Pushing on String: Legal Accountability in the Use of Federal Financial Incentives", 31 Alta. L. Rev. 501 (1993) Hein Online) 

In this paper, "financial incentives" are taken to mean disbursements 18 of
AND
In effect, these programs are assistance, but they are not incentives.

"For" is a term of exclusion

Allegra 2 (Francis M., Judge – United States Court of Federal Claims, "Usibelli Coal Mine, Plaintiff, v. The United States, Defendant", 11-8, 2002 U.S. Claims LEXIS 307, , Lexis)

The cynosure here is the phrase "for any overpayment in respect of any internal
AND
strictly construed.

"Restrictions" are direct governmental limitations —- excludes measures the only have limiting effects

Viterbo 12 (Annamaria, Assistant Professor in International Law – University of Torino, PhD in International Economic Law – Bocconi University and Jean Monnet Fellow – European University Institute, International Economic Law and Monetary Measures: Limitations to States’ Sovereignty and Dispute, p. 166)

In order to distinguish an exchange restriction from a trade measure, the Fund chose not to give
AND
limitation imposed directly on the use of currency in itself, for all purposes.

"On" means in contact with and links "restrictions" only to domestic energy production

Graham 16 (Arthur Butler, "Brief for Appellants – Wilson v. Dorflinger %26 Sons", Court of Appeals – State of New York, Reg. 108, Fol. 387, 1916, p. 11-12)

The Standard Dictionary defines the word "on" as follows:¶ "In or
AND
are controlled by the operator, in whatever direction he may deem advisable.

JOHN BURNES, MICHAEL MCBRIDE, JANNA CHESNO, Van Ness Feldman, Van Ness Feldman maintains one of the most active and prominent LNG practices in the U.S.  Our practice includes the review and negotiation of LNG sale, purchase, and tolling agreements, and due diligence reviews of proposed projects and contracts for financing LNG facilities.  Our team has first-hand experience in obtaining LNG-related permits from DOE and the needed authorizations to construct and operate LNG terminals and related pipeline facilities from FERC.  Further, Van Ness Feldman professionals have worked on every piece of federal energy legislation over the last two decades.  In addition to our representation of existing U.S. pipelines and LNG terminal owners, our team includes members who litigated the Trunkline LNG Project before FERC and DOE where the issue of DOE’s revocation authority arose for the first time, and members with first-hand experience in developing the statutory language of Energy Policy Act of 2005, which facilitated the development of LNG import terminals in the U.S.  For more information, please contact John Burnes, Janna Chesno, Lisa Epifani, Michael McBride, or any member of our LNG practice at 202.298.1800., January 23, 2012, http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html-http://www.vnf.com/news-policyupdates-669.html)

David is a former faculty member of the College of Southern Nevada, where he established the Solar Energy Technology Training Program and the Center for Appropriate Technology in 1976. T vs China Solar Tariffs Aff - 1NC/2NC - Harvard Round 4

Tournament: Harvard | Round: 4 | Opponent: NU BF | Judge: Morris

T vs China Tariffs Aff

1NC

"Energy production" means extraction, capture, or conversion of energy
Comley 9 (Blair, Secretary of the Department of Climate Change – Government of Australia, National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting Streamlining Protocol, http://www.climatechange.gov.au/~~/media/publications/greenhouse-report/nger-streamlining-protocol.pdf)

This section includes definitions of the key terms used in the NGER Act,¶ and outlines the approach used to measure and AND
consumption by or from the operation of the¶ facility or for use other than in the operation of the facility.

"In" means inclusion within —- action must occur within the United States
Random House 12 (Unabridged Dictionary, "in", http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/in?s=t)

in   ~in~  Show IPA preposition, adverb, adjective, noun, verb, inned, in•ning.
AND
5. (used to indicate means): sketched in ink; spoken in French.
That’s the USA
Encarta 7 (Dictionary Online, "United States",  http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/features/dictionary/DictionaryResults.aspx?refid=1861708119)

U•nit•ed States ~ y ntəd stáyts-http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/features/dictionary/Pronounce.aspx?search=United+States ~ country in central North America, consisting of 50 states.
AND
Official name  United States of America
Financial incentives require the disbursement of public funds linked to energy production – excludes action with incentive effects
Webb 93 – lecturer in the Faculty of Law at the University of Ottawa (Kernaghan, "Thumbs, Fingers, and Pushing on String: Legal Accountability in the Use of Federal Financial Incentives", 31 Alta. L. Rev. 501 (1993) Hein Online) 

In this paper, "financial incentives" are taken to mean disbursements 18 of
AND
In effect, these programs are assistance, but they are not incentives.
"For" is a term of exclusion
Allegra 2 (Francis M., Judge – United States Court of Federal Claims, "Usibelli Coal Mine, Plaintiff, v. The United States, Defendant", 11-8, 2002 U.S. Claims LEXIS 307, , Lexis)

The cynosure here is the phrase "for any overpayment in respect of any internal
AND
strictly construed.

"Restrictions" are direct governmental limitations —- excludes measures the only have limiting effects
Viterbo 12 (Annamaria, Assistant Professor in International Law – University of Torino, PhD in International Economic Law – Bocconi University and Jean Monnet Fellow – European University Institute, International Economic Law and Monetary Measures: Limitations to States’ Sovereignty and Dispute, p. 166)

In order to distinguish an exchange restriction from a trade measure, the Fund chose not to give relevance to the
AND
on the use of currency in itself, for all purposes.
"On" means in contact with and links "restrictions" only to domestic energy production
Graham 16 (Arthur Butler, "Brief for Appellants – Wilson v. Dorflinger %26 Sons", Court of Appeals – State of New York, Reg. 108, Fol. 387, 1916, p. 11-12)

The Standard Dictionary defines the word "on" as follows:¶ "In or
AND
are controlled by the operator, in whatever direction he may deem advisable.

2NC

Financial incentives must involve funding transfer and their interpretation makes "restriction" internally bidirectional and impossible to determine – import protections can just as easily be seen as incentives for domestic solar cell production

Czinkota 9 - Associate Professor at the McDonough School of Business at Georgetown University (Michael, Fundamentals of International Business, p. 69)

Incentives offered by policymakers to facilitate foreign investments are mainly of three types: fiscal
AND
import quotas, and local content requirements, and investments in infrastructure facilities.

"Production" refers to quantity extracted from the ground or equivalent amount produced
OECD 10 (Organisation for Economic Co-Operation and Development, OECD Factbook 2010: Economic, Environmental, and Social Statistics, p. 118)
ENERGY PRODUCTION
Energy production is a function of the natural resources of each country and of the economic incentives to exploit AND
which expresses the energy content of each source in million tonnes of oil equivalent (Mtoe) energy.

Recent temperatures show no increase in warming

Happer 12 (William is a professor of physics at Princeton. "Global Warming Models Are Wrong Again", Wall Street Journal, 3/27/12, http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702304636404577291352882984274.html-http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702304636404577291352882984274.html)
What is happening to global temperatures in reality? The answer is: almost nothing for more than 10 years. Monthly values of the global temperature anomaly of the lower atmosphere, compiled at the University of Alabama from NASA satellite data, can be found at the website http://www.drroyspencer.com/latest-global-temperatures/. The latest (February 2012) monthly global temperature anomaly for the lower atmosphere was minus 0.12 degrees Celsius, slightly less than the average since the satellite record of temperatures began in 1979

Net benefit ~%23 2 – Ground Disad

Awehali ’6
(Brian Awehali is an award-winning journalist and former Britannica.com editor. "Awehali," one of several (anglicized) Cherokee spellings for "eagle," and is drawn from the name his great-great-grandmother gave him. It was one of several names he adopted for his public life. His is a tribal member of the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma, Ani-tsiskwa (bird clan). His journalism has centered on Native American issues – most notably editing Tipping the Sacred Cow (AK Press, 2007), an anthology including contributions from Vandana Shiva, Winona LaDuke, Michael Eric Dyson, Timothy Kreider and Christopher Hitchens. He founded the magazine, LiP: Informed Revolt and is the 2006 Project Censored Award winner. His work has been published in dozens of print and online publications, including The Guardian, Z magazine/ZNet, Counterpunch, The Progressive, The Columbia Journalism Review, The Black World Today, Earth Island Journal, and the 2006 and 2007 volumes of Censored: The Top 25 Censored Stories (Seven Stories Press).¶ "NATIVE ENERGY FUTURES: Renewable Energy %26 the New Rush on Indian Lands" – Loud Canary – 6/05/06 – http://loudcanary.com/tag/energy/)

A story frames our point --

 

In 1999, student activism culminated in a meeting between protestors and the Greek Ministry of Education. That meeting was an incredible opportunity for radical reform – but the students failed because Greek curriculum had never taught them how confront systems of domination by using specific clash and line-by-line refutation. 

 

This contextualizes why we think our model of debate is so important.

Fiscal Cliff DA - 1NC/1NR/2NR - Shirley Round 8

Tournament:  | Round:  | Opponent:  | Judge:

sub•stan•tial (sb-stnshl) KEY ¶ ADJECTIVE:¶ Of, relating to, or having substance; material.¶ True or real; not imaginary.¶ Solidly built; strong.¶ Ample; sustaining: a substantial breakfast.¶ Considerable in importance, value, degree, amount, or extent: won by a substantial margin.¶ Possessing wealth or property; well-to-do.

Second – Yes, you link – Kahn’s ecopedagogy is rooted in Freire

Journal of Sustainability Education ’10
May 9th, 2010 – http://www.jsedimensions.org/wordpress/tags/ecopedagogy/

Beth Pollock provides the historical roots and inspiration of Kahn’s Ecopedagogy in Freire and Illich, giving us a good pre-view of what to expect in the book. She finds Kahn’s call for a new kind of pedagogy, founded in these greater thinkers, timely as we work towards establishing educational processes that provide the necessary literacy to face ecological and sustainability issues now and in the future.

Third – Aff Vagueness is a voter. Neg burdens distinct – we react and must brace for contingencies brought-on by vagueness. They have no plan and one-card describing their "pedagogy". On-point book reviews should link. Normatively, they dodge the tough questions – which is educationally what we need addressing.

Impacts:

First – Eco-pedagogy that relies on Freire NEVER solves and boosts Cap

Bowers ’6
C. A. (Chet) Bowers received his Ph. D. in education and social thought from the University of California, taught at the University of Oregon for 25 years, and was granted emeritus status from Portland State University in 1998. He has authored over 105 articles and 22 books (including 4 online books) that deal with educational reforms that focus on the linguistic foundations of the ecological crisis–and more recently, on educational reforms that revitalize the cultural commons as alternatives to a consumer-dependent lifestyle. He has been invited to speak at 34 American universities, and 35 foreign universities – Why the Theories of John Dewey and Paulo Freire Cannot Contribute to Revitalizing the Commons – http://www.centerforecojusticeeducation.org/index.php?option=com_content%26task=view%26id=33%26Itemid=46

AND
of Dewey and Freire as useful sources for resistance to these destructive trends. 

Second – Your Freire-ian assumptions over-jettison – means Aff can’t solve neo-lib or politics.

Bowers ’6
C. A. (Chet) Bowers received his Ph. D. in education and social thought from the University of California, taught at the University of Oregon for 25 years, and was granted emeritus status from Portland State University in 1998. He has authored over 105 articles and 22 books (including 4 online books) that deal with educational reforms that focus on the linguistic foundations of the ecological crisis–and more recently, on educational reforms that revitalize the cultural commons as alternatives to a consumer-dependent lifestyle. He has been invited to speak at 34 American universities, and 35 foreign universities – Why the Theories of John Dewey and Paulo Freire Cannot Contribute to Revitalizing the Commons – http://www.centerforecojusticeeducation.org/index.php?option=com_content%26task=view%26id=33%26Itemid=46

AND
, conserving what remains of our degraded democratic system become even more urgent.

Dr. Richard Slaughter is the president of Foresight International, in Brisbane, Australia. He is a futurist of international standing with a PhD in Futures Studies. He is the author and/or editor of 16 books and has written numerous articles and papers on futures themes and methodologies. He has long-standing professional links with prominent international institutions, organizations and research bodies. Futures – Volume 40, Issue 10, Pages 853-926 (December 2008) – obtained via Science Direct

Awehali ’6
(Brian Awehali is an award-winning journalist and former Britannica.com editor. "Awehali," one of several (anglicized) Cherokee spellings for "eagle," and is drawn from the name his great-great-grandmother gave him. It was one of several names he adopted for his public life. His is a tribal member of the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma, Ani-tsiskwa (bird clan). His journalism has centered on Native American issues – most notably editing Tipping the Sacred Cow (AK Press, 2007), an anthology including contributions from Vandana Shiva, Winona LaDuke, Michael Eric Dyson, Timothy Kreider and Christopher Hitchens. He founded the magazine, LiP: Informed Revolt and is the 2006 Project Censored Award winner. Grande K - he invented it, no one else recognizes. Red pedagogy uses western notions. Red pedagogy harms Native Americans more. Try or die for neg, not them. Plan not tied to red pedagogy. Keep Native American studies and western philosophies separate. 

Wind DA - 

Case - grammar claims counterproductive to framework claims, the aff not inherent because about a 2011 rule already lifted, squo is sufficient to solve paternalism claim, deontological paternalism claims are wrong and impact turned. Liberation won't come from energy industry. Dooms planet if get in bed with energy industry. Ethics decided on consequences. Imperialism is no the root cause of violence.

2NC:
Grande K - if turn red pedagogy, they have to lose. It's a pic, can remove restrictions without red pedagogy. Calderone says Grande ties Native American thought to western philosophy. We should not tie Native American epistemology to Western critical theory, because it would subvert the Native American epistemology. Subverting Native American epistemology would have disastrous culture consequences. Perm doesn't solve, no NB to perm, perm is severance because takes out endorsement of red pedagogy, severance perm is a voter. Alt just takes out red pedagogy.

Case - Read evidence that says DOI already removed the restriction,non-inherent means vote Neg because the Neg can't debate. Read more evidence to show that Plan was already done, claim that even if there is a distinction, squo would be enough to solve. Tribe members may not want oil, gas, and other companies coming in to produce energy on their land. Plan allows fossil fuel exploitation which turns case. status quo energy products solve as long as small and controllable by Native Americans. Tribally owned energy is better than big business. If outcomes net worse, why would paternalism or sovereignty matter if impacts net worse.

1NR Args:
Case  - they misrepresent Native Americans. Energy projects happening now. Restrictions not key. Something specific on the 3504 restrictions.

DA - kicks, but no link arguments prove T abuse.

T - kills education because it's analogous to a pop quiz on unassigned reading. It's hard to win inherency because they will say the 1AC is a performance. Dropped that extra-T is a voter. Their interpretation of debate is wrong, it's about linear thinking and evidence processing. If they don't go for framework, turn is a voter.

2NR Strat:

T - If impact turn restriction they debate then vote Neg. No warrant for why reading T is a voter against Neg.

Concede uniqueness question that Native Americans building renewable energy in squo, no reason why restriction they outline is bad. Default to specific implementation of a specific restriction. They've conceded that tribal councils not always best. Sovereignty solved in squo. Corporate control is a DA to the aff. Corporate control worse than government control.

Impact analysis - we control internal link to worse world for Native Americans. Link turn aff if think corporations worst. Navajo extinction. Squo solves most of the aff, not going for inhenrency, they just provide uniqueness for the turns.

Topical versions of the aff –

lift restrictions on Native American energy production.

 

NRC ‘12

(National Resources Committee –  US House of Representatives –  Committee on Natural Resources – http://naturalresources.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=296902)

NRC ‘12

(National Resources Committee –  US House of Representatives –  Committee on Natural Resources – http://naturalresources.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=296902)

 

Reduces unnecessary and frivolous lawsuits that are specifically designed to prevent Indians from producing energy

AND

A-to “tie to topic”

 

(  ) Slippery slope – why does their “tie to the topic” need to be energy ?... Why couldn’t it be “substantial” ?.. or “the” ?... when the standard devolves to a tie to ANY word – instead of ALL words – it’s the worst form of Aff choice.

 

Heidt ‘5

(David, at that time he was a Debate Coach @ Emory University – now at UMich – “Re: eDebate Re: Zomp and James”, 4-8, http:~/~/mail-a(%%)rchive.com/edebate@ndtceda.com/msg32084.html)

 

Its not a framer's intent argument. Its a context argument. The interpretations of "resolved" that speak to people's ability to personally get off about the topic are stupid (really) b/c they assume "resolved" in the context of a specific agent--ie, "I am resolved to never post on edebate again"--which is different from "Resolved: I should never post on edebate again". The first is a statement of action. The second is a resolution. "Resolved" in the context of a debate topic just means that the community expressed an opinion by voting for a topic.from dictionary.com: 3. A formal resolution made by a deliberative body. Or here's more ev from the Lousiana House: http:~/~/house.louisiana.gov/htm(%%) Resolution  A legislative instrument that generally is used for making declarations, stating policies, and making decisions where some other form is not required. A bill includes the constitutionally required enacting clause; a resolution uses the term "resolved". Not subject to a time limit for introduction nor to governor's veto. ( Const. Art. III, §17(B) and House Rules 8.11 , 13.1 , 6.8 , and 7.4) The debate community is obviously not the legislative body this evidence refers to, but I doub't you'll come up with another definition of "resolved" that both applies it to the resolutional context and even comes close to an alternate interpretation. This is clearly the origin of the word. Now, you can maybe make the argument that context doesn't matter, that we should all make up our own interpretations of what words mean because that's truly liberating, and that you really need to prefer our interpretation b/c its vital to our ability to topically defecate in debate--but any determination that context doesn't matter is also a determination to just ignore the topic altogether. The same reasons to prefer your alternate interpretation of resolved easily justify preferring an alternate, made up interpretation of any other word in the topic. I guess when you say that most no plan teams you've seen are topical, you must really mean that these no plan teams just assert they're germane to the topic b/c at one point they said the word "energy", or maybe just "the", or that they're topical b/c "U.S." means "us" or "resolved" means "ignore everything after the colon". They may have an outrageous interpretation of certain words, but that doesn't make them topical.

 

 

T – AT: Red Pedagogy

 

(  ) Best T card ever – Grande concludes that Red Pedagogy doesn’t dismiss the reformism in our T argument.

 

Grande ‘7

(their author – a chapter from the book Critical Pedagogy, edited by: P McLaren, JL Kincheloe, Chapter 17 by Sany Grande –  Red Lake Woebegone: Pedagogy, Decolonization, and the Critical Project – Page 330-31)

 

Red Pedagogy: Where There Is Resistance There Is Power¶ Audre Lorde s essay

AND

the grammar of empire as just one tool for unthinking our colonial roots.

 

Red Pedagogy doesn’t reject USFG action.

Crum, your author and your book, 6

Steven Crum, Department of Native American Studies, University of California, Davis. “Review of Red Pedagogy: Native American Social and Political Thought By Sandy Grande” Great Plains Research Vol. 16 No. 1, 2006

 

To put the term Red Pedagogy into perspective, the author provides a discussion of

AND

is necessary reading for anyone seeking "emancipatory pedagogies" for indigenous people.

Awehali ’6
(Brian Awehali is an award-winning journalist and former Britannica.com editor. "Awehali," one of several (anglicized) Cherokee spellings for "eagle," and is drawn from the name his great-great-grandmother gave him. It was one of several names he adopted for his public life. His is a tribal member of the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma, Ani-tsiskwa (bird clan). His journalism has centered on Native American issues – most notably editing Tipping the Sacred Cow (AK Press, 2007), an anthology including contributions from Vandana Shiva, Winona LaDuke, Michael Eric Dyson, Timothy Kreider and Christopher Hitchens. He founded the magazine, LiP: Informed Revolt and is the 2006 Project Censored Award winner. His work has been published in dozens of print and online publications, including The Guardian, Z magazine/ZNet, Counterpunch, The Progressive, The Columbia Journalism Review, The Black World Today, Earth Island Journal, and the 2006 and 2007 volumes of Censored: The Top 25 Censored Stories (Seven Stories Press).¶ "NATIVE ENERGY FUTURES: Renewable Energy %26 the New Rush on Indian Lands" – Loud Canary – 6/05/06 – http://loudcanary.com/tag/energy/)

AND

sub•stan•tial (sb-stnshl) KEY ¶ ADJECTIVE:¶ Of, relating to, or having substance; material.¶ True or real; not imaginary.¶ Solidly built; strong.¶ Ample; sustaining: a substantial breakfast.¶ Considerable in importance, value, degree, amount, or extent: won by a substantial margin.¶ Possessing wealth or property; well-to-do.

"Awehali," one of several (anglicized) Cherokee spellings for "eagle," and is drawn from the name his great-great-grandmother gave him. It was one of several names he adopted for his public life. NEPA CP - NU R3

Tournament: NU | Round: 3 | Opponent: Liberty LS | Judge: Nate Cohn

CP

1NC

The United States Federal Government should:

-establish a pilot project that equally considers both environmental harms and benefits of offshore wind plans, projects and policies evaluated under the National Environmental Policy Act,

-issue a National Environmental Policy Act guidance encouraging agencies to utilize "mitigated findings of no significant impacts" for offshore wind projects

-increase staffing and resources dedicated to expediting federal reviews for offshore wind energy projects as per the advocacy of Salter

-Substantially increase research and development funding for offshore wind energy

-Establish long term cash transferable investment and production tax credits and advanced energy project credits for offshore wind energy

-provide coordinated long term purchasing commitments for offshore wind energy for federal lands and building and provide high level commitment and engagement to facilitate coordinated power purchase contracts between project developers and other entities

-not decommission oil rigs

Counterplan solves best – 3 independent mechanisms combine to ensure most rapid approval without reducing environmental review

Trevor Salter, ENVIRONMENTAL LAW AND POLICY JOURNAL
UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, DAVIS

interview was conducted with Robert Bishop, General Counsel of the Nuclear Energy Institute (retired). Mr. Bishop’s full biography and qualifications follow this interview. This interview was conducted via email on October 25, 2012 with questions being asked by Kevin Bertram. Mr. Bishop joined Northeast Utilities in 1977 where, in addition to being Corporate Secretary, his responsibilities included resolving legal issues associated with the licensing and operation of the company’s four nuclear power plants. In 1987, he took the position of Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of Nuclear Management and Resources Council, Inc., a Washington, D.C.-based association that was being established by the nuclear industry to address generic technical, regulatory, and legal issues facing the nuclear energy industry. He served in comparable positions in its successor, the Nuclear Energy Institute, Inc., until his retirement in July, 2005. He is admitted to practice before a number of state and Federal courts, including the U.S. Supreme Court, and was a member the District of Columbia, Connecticut, American and Federal Bar Associations, the International Nuclear Law Association and the International Bar Association Section on Energy and Natural Resources Law, where he served as Chairman of the Nuclear Law Committee. He also had been a member of the Blue Ribbon Panel established by DOE Secretary Adm. James Watkins (USN Ret.) to provide an independent assessment of the Waste Isolation Pilot Project then under construction in New Mexico., 10/25/12, http://debateandtherealworld.com/article.php?id=4

The Department of Defense (DOD) could, and does, utilize its own
AND
decision would also surely, and immediately, be challenged in federal court.

Turns case – litigation delays, mass cost overruns and public backlash

Fahring 11 (T.L., JD – University of Texas Law and Law Clerk – Texas Eleventh Court of Appeals, "Nuclear Uncertainty: A Look at the Uncertainties of a U.S. Nuclear Renaissance", Texas Environmental Law Journal, 41 Tex. Envtl. L.J. 279, Lexis)

03/29/2013

NDT - CP - States - 1NC/2NC

Tournament: NDT | Round: 2 | Opponent: Texas BK | Judge: Susko, A Kall, Vint
The fifty United States state governments should:
provide full funding for all small modular reactor robust detailed design and engineering* and licensing costs
pass uniform legislation modeled on California’s Energy Security Coordination Act
obtain electricity from small modular reactors for mission critical military bases in the United States
And provide loan guarantees, permanent investment and production tax credits, consumption incentives, and collection of interest costs and return on equity during construction of nuclear power plants by establishing a Construction Work in Progress mechanism that uses state funds to offset the costs, for small modular reactors that provide energy for military bases in the United States based on their requested specifications or that meets criteria specified in the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency “Request for Information on Deployable Reactor Technologies for Generating Power and Logistic Fuels”

*The scope of such a DDandE effort would include preparation of construction drawings; the specification of system components; procurement engineering, including the preparation of bid packages for suppliers; a general site layout (that would then be adapted to individual plants); and all nonrecurring design and engineering work at the manufacturing site.
Solves Expedited licensing, costs and widespread commercialization
Rosner, et. al. ‘11 (Robert Rosner, Robert Rosner is an astrophysicist and founding director of the Energy Policy Institute at Chicago. He was the director of Argonne National Laboratory from 2005 to 2009, and Stephen Goldberg, Energy Policy Institute at Chicago, The Harris School of Public Policy Studies, Joseph S. Hezir, Principal, EOP Foundation, Inc., http://epic.uchicago.edu/sites/epic.uchicago.edu/files/uploads/SMRWhite_Paper_Dec.14.2011copy.pdf)

1NR Litigation turn

Bishop, 12
interview was conducted with Robert Bishop, General Counsel of the Nuclear Energy Institute (retired). Mr. Bishop's full biography and qualifications follow this interview. This interview was conducted via email on October 25, 2012 with questions being asked by Kevin Bertram. Mr. Bishop joined Northeast Utilities in 1977 where, in addition to being Corporate Secretary, his responsibilities included resolving legal issues associated with the licensing and operation of the company's four nuclear power plants. In 1987, he took the position of Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary of Nuclear Management and Resources Council, Inc., a Washington, D.C.-based association that was being established by the nuclear industry to address generic technical, regulatory, and legal issues facing the nuclear energy industry. He served in comparable positions in its successor, the Nuclear Energy Institute, Inc., until his retirement in July, 2005. He is admitted to practice before a number of state and Federal courts, including the U.S. Supreme Court, and was a member the District of Columbia, Connecticut, American and Federal Bar Associations, the International Nuclear Law Association and the International Bar Association Section on Energy and Natural Resources Law, where he served as Chairman of the Nuclear Law Committee. He also had been a member of the Blue Ribbon Panel established by DOE Secretary Adm. James Watkins (USN Ret.) to provide an independent assessment of the Waste Isolation Pilot Project then under construction in New Mexico., 10/25/12, http://debateandtherealworld.com/article.php?id=4

for is a term of limit and exclusion - Their financial incentive interpretation proves they don’t meet––webb says funds must targeted at inducing a SPECIFIC activity – and that INDIRECT effects are excluded –their funds are Primarily targeted at inducing distribution and sale, which indirectly effects production

NDT- Case- Towson- 1NC/2NC

Tournament: NDT | Round: 4 | Opponent: TowsonJR | Judge: 

Case

Sexton/Intersectionality Turns

Sexton/Intersectionality Turn – 1NC

(  ) Sexton’s starting point of radical non-communicability cements violence against Native Americans. This is our "external" impact, if you will. 

SMITH ’10

AND

Decentralized Language Turn – 2NC

Decentering of language really does matter. By destroying confidence in the ability to share ideas or values through language, it causes us to remain silent in the face of violence and human extermination. Our alternative of defending the integrity of language and speaking honestly within our community can generate powerful ethical feelings that spill over to other communities.
KETELS ’96 (Violet B., Assoc. prof, of English @ Temple U., director of Intellectual Heritage Program, The American Academy of Political and Social Science. November, p. 1/n GAL)

NDT- K- False Attribution 1NC/2NC

Tournament: NDT | Round: 4 | Opponent: TowsonJR | Judge: 

False Attribution

False Attribution 1NC

There’s VERY strong reason to doubt that there is anything racist or anti-black about asking the aff to defend a topical plan 

Evidence suggests Black consciousness is linked to both strong political mistrust and sense of internal political efficacy – that specific combination is uniquely motivated to participate by a governmental policymaking focus
our ev has broader explanatory power for race based participation decisions, irrefutably backed by multiple studies, strong statistical support, and slays their split consciousness claims
Policy focused Political interest motivates and increases black participation – studies prove – our ev has broader explanatory power for race based participation decisions
Shingles, 81  (Richard, Prof @ Virginia Tech, 
Ph.D., University of Minnesota, associate professor of the Department of Political Science. He a faculty affiliate of the Alliance for Social, Political, Ethical, and Cultural Thought (ASPECT), an adjunct/associate faculty member of: the Center for Interdisciplinary, Africana Studies, Woman and Gender Studies, the Race and Social Policy Center, and the Pamplin Business Diversity Center. Rick is a member of the Multicultural Fellows, which he helped organize in 1998. He serves on the CLAHS Diversity Committee where he chairs the Sponsorship Awards Committee. He has served as an elected member of the Faculty Senate, representing the Political Science and the Black Caucus, the University Council, representing the Commission on Equal Opportunity and Diversity, and the CEOC. He also has served on the Internal Advisor Board of the CLAHS Undergraduate Diversity Certificate, which he helped build, and chaired the CLAHS awards committee for the Summer Graduate Student Diversity Fellowship, which he helped create.  Rick’s research, teaching and service focus on race, ethnicity, class and gender. He teaches two courses for the Graduate Diversity Certificate Program, from a comparative minority group and history perspective. One is on the role of the state in the social construction of race and the maintenance of white privilege, and the other addresses identity, critical consciousness and agency of minorities resisting oppression. His articles have been published in the American Political Science Review, Journal of Politics, Law and Public Policy, Political Behavior, Policy Studies Journal, Political Methodology, Experimental Study of Politics, Journal of Black Studies, and the American Educational Research Journal.The American Political Science Review, Vol. 75, No. 1 (Mar., 1981), pp. 76-91, http://www.jstor.org/stable/1962160 .
Recent research has demonstrated that black Americans are far more politically active than whites of
AND
participation over another and how the choice varies by race and social class.

NDT Rd 6 Reverse Auction CP 1NC

Tournament:  | Round:  | Opponent: UNLV BV | Judge: 

Auction CP

1NC

The United States federal government should:
-Conduct a reverse subsidy auction to conclude after a three-month bidding process, giving subsidies to energy producers with the lowest bids within specific energy categories allowing technologies of similar maturity levels to compete amongst themselves using the methodology described in our Wood evidence.
-Create a tech-neutral criteria for technical evaluation that includes the ability to replace conventional coal plants and meet the framework for cooperation with the People’s Republic of China at the U.S.-China Clean Energy Research Center
-Establish a dedicated trust fund for the distribution of monies awarded at auction.
-Conduct similar auctions every six months over a period of ten years. Subsequent auctions should include competition between producers based on relative price gains

Counterplan solves technical viability and commercial success
Wood 12 (Tony, Energy Program Director at the Grattan Institute, an Australian think tank, "Auctioning off a reduced carbon future," 7/16, http://grattan.edu.au/static/files/assets/2273ec90/160_wood_oped_businessspectator_energy.pdf-http://grattan.edu.au/static/files/assets/2273ec90/160_wood_oped_businessspectator_energy.pdf)

This report describes a proposal for government to enter into long-term contracts with
AND
and other auction programs where winning projects often fail to achieve commercial close.
Creates a competitive energy market and better tech  - auction will incentivize aff tech for 4 reasons
- multiple auction rounds
- with multiple winners per round make incentives for aff tech highly likely but not guaranteed
– 1ac claim that incentives generate major cost gains for  ensures it wins out at auction over time because of relative cost reduction criteria
-Limited to tech of similar maturity level
Wood 12 (Tony, Energy Program Director at the Grattan Institute, an Australian think tank, "Low-emission’s missing link: reverse auctions for clean power," 7/17, http://grattan.edu.au/static/files/assets/75892b98/163_wood_oped_conversation_energy.pdf-http://grattan.edu.au/static/files/assets/75892b98/163_wood_oped_conversation_energy.pdf)

Allocate contracts through low-bid auctions To overcome this problem, the Grattan Institute’s
AND
will gain further support. Technologies that do not will have support withdrawn.
A tech-neutral competitive bidding process avoids picking winners and guarantees efficiency
Koplow 11 (David, member of the Union of Concerned Scientists, "Nuclear Power: Still Not Viable Without Subsidies," http://www.ucsusa.org/assets/documents/nuclear_power/nuclear_subsidies_report.pdf-http://www.ucsusa.org/assets/documents/nuclear_power/nuclear_subsidies_report.pdf) 

Award subsidies to low-carbon energy sources on the basis of a competitive bidding
AND
of their bids to accept the lowest subsidy per kilowatt-hour delivered.
Setting technical criteria means winning tech will be tailored to private sector needs
Wu 10 (Irene, Acting Chief Data Officer, International Bureau, FCC, "Maximum Impact for Minimum Subsidy: Reverse Auctions for Universal Access in Chile and India," October, http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DOC-302511A1.pdf-http://hraunfoss.fcc.gov/edocs_public/attachmatch/DOC-302511A1.pdf)

First, technical evaluations create incentive for high performance. Before bids go into the auction, they are reviewed by technical experts at the regulator. It appears that only the bids ranked as performing the highest from a technical perspective are forwarded to the auction. This may give bidders an incentive not only to minimize the requested subsidy, but also at least achieve and perhaps exceed the technical and service requirements for the project at hand.

NDT Rd 6 QER CP 1NC/2NC New

Tournament:  | Round:  | Opponent: UNLV BV | Judge: 

QER

1NC

The United States Congress should:
 immediately require a government-wide Quadrennial Energy Review
through a staged process to be completed by February 1st each year, concluded in entirety by February 1st, 2015, and every subsequent four years
led by the President in coordination with the Secretary of Energy as Executive Secretariat, giving them final authority over its content
to recommend goals, priorities and actions for implementation of a national energy policy

provide all necessary support for expedited build up of relevant analytic capabilities

and pass a non-binding concurrent congressional resolution of both houses demanding implementation of review outcomes as a national energy policy imperative

The President and Executive Secretariat should immediately establish a policy determination to provide full support to make a top priority of the first stage of recommendations that the United States Federal Government provide loan guarantees for power plants that employ coal-direct chemical looping in the United States. .

Experts agree it’s the single most important energy policy, spurs implementation and avoids budget fights
Chu Et al, 11
(Steven, DOE QTR, pdf)

When PCAST recommended the DOE QTR, the most important recommendation was the development of
AND
the support of an  Executive Secretariat, provided by the Secretary of Energy. 

7 reasons our process is key – Solves Certainty Better
- EOP powers ensure effective executive and agency implementation
- Provides strong analytic base depoliticizing dialogue and ensures policy support regardless of political shifts or composition
- Increases prioritization - Spurs focused and effective prioritization effort
- increases transparency
- overcomes SQ fragmented decisionmaking processes
- structurally ensures coordinated dialogue
- mobilizes industry support
Moniz, 11
Ernest J. Moniz, Cecil and Ida Green, Professor  of Physics and Engineering Systems, Director, MIT Energy Initiative, 11/15, http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-112shrg72188/html/CHRG-112shrg72188.htm)

An integrated Federal energy policy up to these challenges needs  staying power, and that
AND
engagement with the QER/QTR process  will be important for its success.

Solves Signal immediately and independently solves even if it doesn’t result in the aff
- develops framework for decisionmaking that facilitates cohesive policymaking
- avoids spending fights through better targeting and prioritization
- initial creation of QER sends visible congressional signal that makes backtracking and partisan obstruction difficult
- QDR proves it generates consensus
Begich, 11  (Mark, US Senator, Congressional Documents and Publications, 10/13, lexis)

The Quadrennial Energy Review Act of 2011 authorizes a high-level government-wide
AND
efficiently meets our energy needs. This bill will help us do that."


Results not released in advanced – QTR proves
Fuel Cell Insider, 7/14/11
While it is clear that fuel cells are not front and center for the DOE
AND
receive all comments at gov.

2NC Binding Enactment/CR Trick

The 2AC answers the GSU version of QER, not the NDT version – we include a nonbinding congressional resolution of support for the plan. That means CP sends signal immediately solving aff and results in future binding enactment – perm can’t solve because immediate legislation links to politics –
Posner ’8 Eric A, Professor of Law, The University of Chicago and  Jacob E. Gersen, Assistant Professor of Law, The University of Chicago. Stanford LR, December

When the lawmaking agent does not comply with the rules, its communications will not
AND
resolutions is no easier or harder than identifying the content of hard resolutions. 

Causes president implementation, solves any signal argument immediately and causes future congressional approval – perm can’t solve link because prior passage of the resolution is key
Posner ’8 Eric A, Professor of Law, The University of Chicago and  Jacob E. Gersen, Assistant Professor of Law, The University of Chicago. Stanford LR, December
This is not, however, the only way for a soft statute to affect
AND
the cooperation of these groups, the soft statute influences future presidential decisions. 

Captures all upsides of formal legislation via congressional signal , perception of future legislation and anticipatory changes by stakeholders -  our ev assumes energy policy and investment decisions
Posner ’8 Eric A, Professor of Law, The University of Chicago and  Jacob E. Gersen, Assistant Professor of Law, The University of Chicago. Stanford LR, December

AND

NDT Round 7: Equip CP 1NC

Tournament:  | Round:  | Opponent:  | Judge:
EQUIP CP
United States Congress should:

approve leasing of crude oil by entities that wish to engage in joint crude oil production with Cuban energy-producing entities in the area of the Gulf of Mexico’s Eastern Gap included in the United States’ Outer Continental Shelf Planning areas for non drilling and production activities.

maintain its restrictions on joint crude oil production with Cuban energy-producing entities in the area of the Gulf of Mexico’s Eastern Gap included in the United States’ Outer Continental Shelf Planning areas.
add to that restriction, through explicit statutory authorization and mandated enactment, an alternate penalty option allowing violator opt-in to penalization solely through entry into a Supplemental Environmental Program requiring payment of 1% of revenue from all violating activities to an Environmental Quality Incentives Program which provides farmers with financial and technical assistance to plan and implement soil conservation practices as per the advocacy of our Stubbs evidence, with violator implementation of the alternate penalty program expressly providing shield from additional legal penalties stemming from the violating action, including citizen suits, state law penalties, and program publicity limitations

 And Statutorily clarify that the above act is narrowly exempt from, and supercedes, all potential conflicting laws and regulations

United States Federal Government should modify all relevant federal laws, regulations, agency rules, policies and guidelines accordingly.
EQIP underfunded now – cp key to sustain
Stubbs 10 (Megan, CRS Analyst in Agricultural Conservation and Natural Resources Policy, “Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP): Status and Issues,” 8/13, http://www.nationalaglawcenter.org/assets/crs/R40197.pdf)
The Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) is a voluntary program that provides farmers
AND
EQIP will also continue to face challenges in measuring environmental and program accomplishments. 

EQIP solves soil erosion
NRCS 13 (Natural Resources Conservation Service, “South Carolina FY 2013 EQIP Sign-Up and Application Information,” http://www.sc.nrcs.usda.gov/programs/eqip/eqip2012.html)
Conservation Programs Protect Soil, Water, and Wildlife EQIP helps farmers improve production while
AND
who want to improve wildlife habitat or restore natural ecosystems on their land.
Soil erosion ends civilization – yes, we’re serious
Montgomery 7 (David R. Montgomery, Quaternary Research Center and Department of Earth and Space Sciences, University of Washington, http://www.geosociety.org/gsatoday/archive/17/10/pdf/i1052-5173-17-10-4.pdf)

AND

NDT Round 7: 1NC/2NC OIRA CP

Tournament:  | Round:  | Opponent:  | Judge: 

The United States Federal Government should immediately initiate Executive Order 12866, 13563, 13579, 13609 and 13610 “early actions” regulatory “lookback” review of joint crude oil production with Cuban energy-producing entities in the area of the Gulf of Mexico’s Eastern Gap included in the United States’ Outer Continental Shelf Planning areas restrictions and immediately invite the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs to, through informal review: participate, provide information analysis and recommendations, and allow interested regulated parties, stakeholders, and federal agencies to provide comment through scheduled meetings.

McCardle and Yahle, 11

AND

Kennedy, 3/9/13
Jessica Kennedy, Energy Curtailment Specialists Inc., Jessica has worked in the energy industry since 2008. She has a master’s degree in Physical Geography and Environmental Systems from SUNY at Buffalo. Michael E. Kraft is professor emeritus of political science and public affairs and Herbert Fisk Johnson Professor of Environmental Studies emeritus at the University of Wisconsin-Green Bay. He is the author of Environmental Policy and Politics (5th ed., Pearson Longman 2011 ), co-author of Public Policy: Politics, Analysis, and Alternatives (4th edition, 2012), and co-author of Coming Clean: Information Disclosure and Environmental Performance (MIT Press 2011). In addition, he is co-editor of Environmental Policy : New Directions for the Twenty-First Century, 8th ed. (2012), with Norman J. Vig; Business and Environmental Policy (2007) and The Oxford Handbook of U.S. Environmental Policy (2012), with Sheldon Kamieniecki; and Toward Sustainable Communities: Transition and Transformations in Environmental Policy, 2nd ed. (2009), with Daniel A. Mazmanian.
